name: init [path]
options: initialize an empty bit bare scope
add group write permissions to a scope properly
do not nest component store within .git directory and do not write config data inside package.json
write missing or damaged Bit files
reset .bitmap file as if the components were newly added and remove all model data (objects)
delete all Bit files and directories, including Bit configuration, tracking and model data. Useful for re-start using Bit from scratch
set up default directory to import components into
set up package manager (npm or yarn)
force workspace initialization without clearing local objects
DEPRECATED. no need for this flag. Harmony is the default now
description: create or reinitialize an empty workspace
extendedDescription: https://bit.dev/docs/workspace/creating-workspaces#initialize-a-workspace-on-an-existing-project

name: config
description: global config management
extendedDescription: https://bit.dev/docs/config/bit-config

commands.name: set <key> <val>
commands.description: set a global configuration

commands.name: del <key>
commands.description: delete given key from global configuration

commands.name: get <key>
commands.description: get a global configuration

commands.name: list
commands.description: list all configuration(s)

name: remote
description: manage set of tracked bit scope(s)
extendedDescription: https://bit.dev/docs/scope/remote-scopes

commands.name: add <url>
commands.description: add a bare-scope as a remote
commands.extendedDescription:
supported protocols are [file, http].
for example: "http://localhost:3000", "file:///tmp/local-scope"

commands.name: del <name>
options: remove a global configured remote scope
commands.description: remove a tracked bit remote

name: cat-object <hash>
options:
JSON.stringify the object to see special characters, such as "
"
description: cat a bit object by hash

name: cat-component [id]
description: cat a bit object by component-id

name: cat-lane <id>
description: cat a bit object by lane-name

name: dependents <component-name>
description: EXPERIMENTAL. show dependents of the given component

name: dependencies <component-name>
options: render dependencies as a tree, similar to "npm ls"
show the immediate dependencies and how their version was determined
description: EXPERIMENTAL. show direct and indirect dependencies of the given component

name: _log <path> <args>
description: show component logs

name: _put <path> <args>
description: upload a component to a scope

name: _list <path> <args>
description: list scope components

name: _show <path> <args>
description: show a specific component on scope

name: _graph <path> <args>
description: returns scope graph or sub-graph when component id is given

name: _fetch <path> <args>
description: fetch components(s) from a scope

name: _action <path> <args>
description: execute a generic action

name: _scope <path> <args>
description: describe a scope

name: cat-scope [scopePath]
options: show all of the objects in the scope (except "Source")
print the objects as a json format
add hash and object type to the json
description: cat a scope and show all the contents

name: scope-config
description: scope config management

commands.name: set <key> <val>
commands.description: set a scope configuration

commands.name: del <key>
commands.description: delete given key from global configuration

commands.name: get <key>
commands.description: get a scope configuration

commands.name: list
commands.description: list all scope configuration(s)

name: dependency-status [mainFile...]
description: returns the status of the dependency status of bit map against bit dependencies

name: add [path...]
options: define entry point for the components
override existing component if exists (default = false)
sets the component's scope-name. if not entered, the default-scope will be used
description: Add any subset of files to be tracked as a component(s).
extendedDescription:
all flags support glob patterns and {PARENT} {FILE_NAME} annotations
  https://bit.dev/docs/components/adding-components

name: untag [component-name] [component-version]
options: revert tag for all tagged components
harmony - revert only soft-tags (components tagged with --soft flag)
revert the tag even if used as a dependency. WARNING: components that depend on this tag will corrupt
description: revert tagged or snapped versions for component(s)
extendedDescription:
https://bit.dev/docs/components/tags#undoing-a-tag
you can use a pattern for multiple ids, such as bit untag "utils/*". (wrap the pattern with quotes to avoid collision with shell commands)

name: move <current-component-dir> <new-component-dir>
description: move a component to a different filesystem path
extendedDescription:
move files or directories of component(s)
  https://bit.dev/docs/workspace/moving-components

name: remove <component-ids...>
options: remove a component from a remote scope
keep tracking component in .bitmap (default = false), helps transform a tagged-component to new
DEPRECATED (this is now the default). delete local component files
keep component files (just untrack the component)
removes the component from the scope, even if used as a dependency. WARNING: components that depend on this component will corrupt
description: remove component(s) from the workspace, or a remote scope
extendedDescription:
https://bit.dev/docs/components/removing-components
you can use a pattern for multiple ids, such as bit remove "utils/*". (wrap the pattern with quotes to avoid collision with shell commands)

name: _delete <path> <args>
description: remove a component from a scope

name: _latest <path> <args>
description: latest version numbers of given components

name: checkout [values...]
options: when a component is modified and the merge process found conflicts, display options to resolve them
in case of a conflict, override the used version with the current modification
in case of a conflict, override the current modification with the specified version
in case of a conflict, leave the files with a conflict state to resolve them manually later
revert changes that were not snapped
do not install packages of the imported components
do not generate package.json for the imported component(s). (it automatically enables skip-npm-install and save-dependencies-as-components flags)
write the configuration file (bit.json) and the envs configuration files (use --conf without path to write to the default dir)
do not write dist files (when exist)
description: switch between component versions or remove local changes
extendedDescription:
`bit checkout <version> [ids...]` => checkout the specified ids (or all components when --all is used) to the specified version
  `bit checkout latest` => checkout all components to their latest versions
  `bit checkout latest [ids...]` => checkout the specified ids to their latest versions
  `bit checkout [ids...] --reset` => remove local modifications from the specified ids (or all components when --all is used)
  you can use a pattern for multiple ids, such as bit checkout 0.0.1 "utils/*". (wrap the pattern with quotes to avoid collision with shell commands)

name: diff [values...]
options: show a more verbose output when possible
show tables instead of plain text for dependencies diff
description: show the diff between the components' source files and config
extendedDescription:
bit diff => compare all modified components to their model version
  bit diff [ids...] => compare the specified components against their modified states
  bit diff [id] [version] => compare the specified version to used or modified files
  bit diff [id] [version] [to_version] => compare the specified version files to to_version files
  you can use a pattern for multiple ids, such as bit diff "utils/*". (wrap the pattern with quotes to avoid collision with shell commands)

name: login
options: port number to open for localhost server (default 8085)
do not open a browser for authentication
path to npmrc file to configure bit.cloud registry
specify machine-name to pair with the token (useful for CI to avoid accidentally revoke the token)
description: log in to Bit cloud

name: logout
description: log the CLI out of Bit

name: migrate [scopePath]
options: showing logs for the migration process
description: migrate scope to the current version

name: doctor [diagnosis-name]
description: diagnose a bit workspace

name: graph [id]
options: image path. use one of the following extensions: [gif, png, svg, pdf]
remote name (name is optional, leave empty when id is specified)
enter all components versions into the graph, not only latest
GraphVis layout. default to "dot". options are [circo, dot, fdp, neato, osage, patchwork, sfdp, twopi]
description: EXPERIMENTAL. generate an image file with the dependencies graph

name: fetch [ids...]
options: EXPERIMENTAL. fetch component objects from lanes. note, it does not save the remote lanes objects locally, only the refs
fetch indirect dependencies from their original scope as opposed to from their dependents
description: fetch remote objects and store locally
extendedDescription: for lanes, use "/" as a separator between the remote and the lane name, e.g. teambit.ui/fix-button

name: run-action <action-name> <remote> <options>
description: run an action on a remote

name: _lanes <path> <args>
description: list lanes

name: completion
description: enable bash/zsh-completion shortcuts for commands and options

name: cli
description: EXPERIMENTAL. enters bit cli program and generates commands list

commands.name: generate
options: metadata/front-matter to place at the top of the .md file, enter as an object e.g. --metadata.id=cli --metadata.title=commands
output the commands info as JSON
commands.description: EXPERIMENTAL. generate an .md file with all commands details

name: help
description: shows help

name: show <component-name>
options: return the component data in a json format
compare current file system component to the latest tagged component [default=latest]. only works in legacy.
description: display the component's essential information

arguments.name: component-name
arguments.description: component name or component id

name: envs
description: list all components maintained by the workspace and their corresponding envs

commands.name: list
commands.description: list all envs available in the workspace

commands.name: get <component-name>
commands.description: show information about a component's env

arguments.name: component-name
arguments.description: the 'component name' or 'component id' of the component its env you'd like to inspect

commands.name: set <component-pattern> <env>
commands.description: Sets one or more components with a development environment (env)

arguments.name: component-pattern
arguments.description:
component name, component id, or component pattern. use component pattern to select multiple components.
use comma to separate patterns and "!" to exclude. e.g. "ui/**, !ui/button"
wrap the pattern with quotes

arguments.name: env
arguments.description: the env's component id (include version for non-core envs. e.g, `teambit.community/envs/community-react@1.95.13`)

examples.description: configures all components that have the 'ui' namespace to use the teambit.react/react env

commands.name: unset <component-pattern>
commands.description: un-sets an env from components that were previously set by "bit env set" or by a component template
commands.extendedDescription:
keep in mind that this doesn't remove envs that are set in the variants.
in only removes envs that appear in the .bitmap file, which were previously configured via "bit env set".
the purpose of this command is to remove the specific settings and let the the variants in workspace.jsonc to control the env.
you can use a `<pattern>` for multiple component ids, such as `bit env unset "org.scope/utils/**"`.
use comma to separate patterns and "!" to exclude. e.g. "ui/**, !ui/button"
always wrap the pattern with quotes to avoid collision with shell commands.
use `bit pattern --help` to understand patterns better and `bit pattern <pattern>` to validate the pattern.

arguments.name: component-pattern
arguments.description:
component name, component id, or component pattern. use component pattern to select multiple components. 
use comma to separate patterns and "!" to exclude. e.g. "ui/**, !ui/button"
wrap the pattern with quotes

commands.name: replace <current-env> <new-env>
commands.description: replace an existing env with another env for all components using the old env

arguments.name: current-env
arguments.description: the component id of the current env

arguments.name: new-env
arguments.description: the component id of the new env

examples.description: components configured to use the 'aspect' env will be configured to use the 'node' env, instead

name: globals
description: list all globals

name: start [type] [pattern]
options: start UI server in dev mode.
show verbose output for inspection and prints stack trace
do not automatically open browser when ready
skip the auto-compilation before starting the web-server
description: run the ui/development server

name: ui-build [type]
description: build production assets for deployment.

name: scope <sub-command>
description: EXPERIMENTAL. manage the scope-name for components

commands.name: set <scope-name> [component-pattern]
commands.description: Sets components with a default-scope. If no component is specified, sets the workspace with a default scope
commands.extendedDescription:
default scopes for components are set in the bitmap file. the default scope for a workspace is set in the workspace.jsonc. a component is set with a scope (as oppose to default scope) only once it is versioned.'

you can use a `<pattern>` for multiple component ids, such as `bit scope set scope-name "org.scope/utils/**"`.
use comma to separate patterns and "!" to exclude. e.g. "ui/**, !ui/button"
always wrap the pattern with quotes to avoid collision with shell commands.
use `bit pattern --help` to understand patterns better and `bit pattern <pattern>` to validate the pattern.

arguments.name: scope-name
arguments.description: the scope name to use as the default scope

arguments.name: component-pattern
arguments.description:
component name, component id, or component pattern. use component pattern to select multiple components. 
use comma to separate patterns and "!" to exclude. e.g. "ui/**, !ui/button"
wrap the pattern with quotes

commands.name: rename <current-scope-name> <new-scope-name>
options: update the import statements in all dependent components to the new package name (that contains the new scope name)
commands.description: Renames the scope name for all components with the specified 'current scope name'

arguments.name: current-scope-name
arguments.description: the scope name to be replaced by another scope name

arguments.name: new-scope-name
arguments.description: a new scope name to replace the current scope name

commands.name: fork <original-scope> <new-scope>
commands.description: fork all components of the original-scope and refactor the source-code to use the new package names

name: install [packages...]
options: "runtime" (default) or "peer" (dev is not a valid option)
update existing dependencies version and types
set the prefix to use when adding dependency to workspace.jsonc
do not dedupe dependencies on installation
do not import bit objects post installation
description: installs workspace dependencies
extendedDescription: when no package is specified, all workspace dependencies are installed and all workspace components are imported.

arguments.name: packages...
arguments.description: a list of packages to install (separated by spaces)

name: update
description: update dependencies

name: uninstall [packages...]
description: uninstall dependencies

name: eject-conf <pattern>
options: mark propagate true in the config file
description: eject components configuration (create a `component.json` file)
extendedDescription:
you can use a `<pattern>` for multiple component ids, such as `bit eject-conf "org.scope/utils/**"`.
use comma to separate patterns and "!" to exclude. e.g. "ui/**, !ui/button"
always wrap the pattern with quotes to avoid collision with shell commands.
use `bit pattern --help` to understand patterns better and `bit pattern <pattern>` to validate the pattern.

name: capsule <sub-command>
description: manage capsules
extendedDescription:
a capsule is a directory containing the component code, isolated from the workspace.
normally, capsules are created during the build process, the component files are copied and the packages are installed
via the configured package-manager. the purpose is to compile/test them in isolation to make sure they will work for
other users after publishing/exporting them.

commands.name: list
commands.description: list the capsules generated for this workspace

commands.name: create [component-id...]
options: set base dir of all capsules (hashed to create the base dir inside the root dir - host path by default)
set root base dir of all capsules (absolute path to use as root dir)
create capsules for the seeders only (not for the entire graph)
npm, yarn or pnpm, default to npm
commands.description: create capsules for components

commands.name: delete
options: delete all capsules for all workspaces and scopes
commands.description: delete capsules
commands.extendedDescription: with no args, only workspace's capsules are deleted

name: watch
options: show npm verbose output for inspection and print the stack trace
skip the compilation step before starting to watch
EXPERIMENTAL. show errors/warnings for types. options are [file, project] to investigate only changed file or entire project. defaults to project
description: automatically recompile modified components (on save)

name: link [component-names...]
options: Replace relative paths with module paths in code (e.g. "../foo" => "@bit/foo")
EXPERIMENTAL. link to an external directory (similar to npm-link) so other projects could use these components
skip fetch missing objects from remotes before linking
description: create links in the node_modules directory, to core aspects and to components in the workspace
extendedDescription: https://bit.dev/docs/workspace/component-links

arguments.name: component-names...
arguments.description: names or IDs of the components to link

name: use <component-id>
description: set aspects in the workspace/scope config to make them loadable by the workspace/scope

arguments.name: component-id
arguments.description: the component ID of the aspect

name: pattern <pattern>
description: list the component ids matching the given pattern
extendedDescription:
this command helps validating a pattern before using it in other commands.
a pattern can be a simple component-id or component-name. e.g. "ui/button".
a pattern can be used with wildcards for multiple component ids, e.g. "org.scope/utils/**".
to enter multiple patterns, separate them by a comma, e.g. "ui/*, lib/*"
to exclude, use "!". e.g. "ui/**, !ui/button"
always wrap the pattern with quotes to avoid collision with shell commands.
the matching algorithm is done by multimatch (@see https://github.com/sindresorhus/multimatch)

examples.description: matches components with any scope-name and the "ui" namespace. e.g. "ui/button" but not "ui/elements/button"
matches components that their namespace starts with "ui/" e.g. "ui/button", "ui/elements/button"
matches two components: bar and foo
matches all components of the scope "my-scope.org"

name: list [remote-scope]
options: show only components stored in the local scope, including indirect dependencies
show the output in JSON format
show only specified namespace by using wildcards
description: list components on a workspace, local scope or a remote scope.
extendedDescription: https://bit.dev/docs/reference/cli-reference#list

name: import [component-ids...]
options: import components into a specific directory (a relative path in the workspace)
import components objects to the local scope without checkout (without writing them to the file system). This is a default behavior for import with no id argument
write the configuration file (component.json) of the component
do not install packages of the imported components
merge local changes with the imported version. strategy should be "theirs", "ours" or "manual"
EXPERIMENTAL. import all dependencies and write them to the workspace
EXPERIMENTAL. import the components' dependents. this enables changes to propagate from (modified) components to their dependents
EXPERIMENTAL. when checked out to a lane and the component is not on the remote-lane, save it in the lane (default to save on main)
relevant for fetching all components objects. avoid optimizations, fetch all history versions, always
description: import components from remote scopes to the local workspace
extendedDescription:
https://bit.dev/docs/components/importing-components
you can use a pattern for multiple ids, such as bit import "utils/*". (wrap the pattern with quotes to avoid collision with shell commands)

arguments.name: component-ids...
arguments.description: a list of component IDs (separated by space) to import

name: create <template-name> <component-names...>
options: sets the component's namespace and nested dirs inside the scope
sets the component's scope-name. if not entered, the default-scope will be used
aspect-id of the template. helpful when multiple aspects use the same template name
relative path in the workspace. by default the path is `<scope>/<namespace>/<name>`
set the component's environment. (overrides the env from variants and the template)
description: create a new component (source files and config) using a template.

arguments.name: template-name
arguments.description:
the template for generating the component 
(run 'bit templates' for a list of available templates)

arguments.name: component-names...
arguments.description: a list of component names to generate

examples.description: creates a component named 'ui/button' using the 'react' template
creates two components, 'ui/button' and 'pages/register', using the 'react' template

creates a component named 'ui/button' and sets it scope to 'my-org.my-scope'. 
by default, the scope is the `defaultScope` value, configured in your `workspace.jsonc`.

creates a component named 'ui/button' and sets it to use the 'community-react' env. 
(the template's default env is 'teambit.react/react').

name: templates
description: list templates for "bit create" and "bit new"
extendedDescription: list components templates when inside bit-workspace (for bit-create), otherwise, list workspace templates (for bit-new)

name: new <template-name> <workspace-name>
options: aspect-id of the template. mandatory for non-core aspects. helpful for core aspects in case of a name collision
set defaultScope in the new workspace.jsonc
empty workspace with no components (relevant for templates that add components by default)
path to the workspace containing the template. helpful during a development of a workspace-template
description: create a new workspace from a template

arguments.name: template-name
arguments.description: the name of the workspace template (run 'bit templates', outside of a workspace, to get a list of available templates)

arguments.name: workspace-name
arguments.description: the name for the new workspace and workspace directory

name: build [component-pattern]
options: build all components, not only modified and new
run the pipeline in dev mode
avoid deleting the capsules root-dir before starting the build

build the specified task(s) only. for multiple tasks, separate by a comma and wrap with quotes.
specify the task-name (e.g. "TypescriptCompiler") or the task-aspect-id (e.g. teambit.compilation/compiler)
set the package-manager cache on the capsule root
list tasks of an env or a component-id for each one of the pipelines: build, tag and snap
description: run set of tasks for build

arguments.name: component-pattern
arguments.description:
component name, component id, or component pattern. use component pattern to select multiple components.
use comma to separate patterns and "!" to exclude. e.g. "ui/**, !ui/button"
wrap the pattern with quotes

name: artifacts <component-pattern>
options: show/download only artifacts generated by this aspect-id
show/download only artifacts generated by this task-id
show/download only artifacts matching the given files or the glob pattern (wrap glob patterns in quotes)
download the files to the specified dir
description: EXPERIMENTAL. list and download components artifacts
extendedDescription:
artifacts are created on isolated capsules during tag or snap commands.
example of artifacts are dists files generated by a compiler, a JUnit.xml file generated by a tester
and a package.tgz file generated by pkg aspect.

arguments.name: component-pattern
arguments.description:
component name, component id, or component pattern. use component pattern to select multiple components.
use comma to separate patterns and "!" to exclude. e.g. "ui/**, !ui/button"
wrap the pattern with quotes

name: pack <componentId> [scopePath]
options: directory to put the result tar file
description: create tar for npm publish

name: publish <componentId>
options: allow publish components that were not exported yet (not recommended)
description: publish components to npm (npm publish)

name: refactor <sub-command>
description: EXPERIMENTAL. source code refactoring / codemod

commands.name: dependency-name <old-id> <new-id>
commands.description: replace the dependency's old package-name with a new one in the code
commands.extendedDescription: the `<old-id>` and `<new-id>` arguments can be either a component-id or a package-name.

name: component-issues
description: list available component-issues

name: insights [names...]
options: return the insights in json format
description: Insights on component graph

name: tag [component-patterns...]
options: a log message describing latest changes
include unmodified components (by default, only new and modified components are tagged)
EXPERIMENTAL. open an editor to write a tag message for each component. optionally, specify the editor-name (defaults to vim).
options are: [major, premajor, minor, preminor, patch, prepatch, prerelease], default to patch
EXPERIMENTAL. tag components that their head is a snap (not a tag)
skip running component tests during tag process
do not persist. only keep note of the changes to be made
persist the changes generated by --soft tag
skip the tag pipeline to avoid publishing the components
run the tag pipeline although the build failed
(default to 1) increment semver flag (patch/minor/major) by. e.g. incrementing patch by 2: 0.0.1 -> 0.0.3.

ignore component issues (shown in "bit status" as "issues found"), issues to ignore:
[MissingPackagesDependenciesOnFs, MissingComponents, UntrackedDependencies, ResolveErrors, RelativeComponents, RelativeComponentsAuthored, ParseErrors, MissingDists, LegacyInsideHarmony, MissingDependenciesOnFs, ImportNonMainFiles, CustomModuleResolutionUsed, MultipleEnvs, MissingLinksFromNodeModulesToSrc, CircularDependencies]
to ignore multiple issues, separate them by a comma and wrap with quotes. to ignore all issues, specify "*".
ignore existing of newer versions (default = false)
EXPERIMENTAL. not needed for now. run the pipeline build and complete the tag
DEPRECATED (not needed anymore, it is the default now). tag all new and modified components
DEPRECATED (use "--unmodified" instead). tag all components of the current scope
DEPRECATED (use "--skip-tests" or "--unmodified" instead). force-tag even if tests are failing and even when component has not changed
description: create an immutable and exportable component snapshot, tagged with a release version.
extendedDescription:
if no patterns are provided, it will tag all new and modified components.
if patterns are entered, you can specify a version per pattern using "@" sign, e.g. bit tag foo@1.0.0 bar@minor baz@major
https://bit.dev/components/tags

arguments.name: component-patterns...
arguments.description: a list of component names, IDs or patterns (separated by space). run "bit pattern --help" to get more data about patterns. By default, all modified are tagged.

name: snap [component-pattern]
options: log message describing the latest changes
include unmodified components (by default, only new and modified components are snapped)
Harmony only. run the pipeline build and complete the tag
skip running component tests during snap process
Harmony only. run the deploy pipeline although the build failed

ignore component issues (shown in "bit status" as "issues found"), issues to ignore:
[MissingPackagesDependenciesOnFs, MissingComponents, UntrackedDependencies, ResolveErrors, RelativeComponents, RelativeComponentsAuthored, ParseErrors, MissingDists, LegacyInsideHarmony, MissingDependenciesOnFs, ImportNonMainFiles, CustomModuleResolutionUsed, MultipleEnvs, MissingLinksFromNodeModulesToSrc, CircularDependencies]
to ignore multiple issues, separate them by a comma and wrap with quotes. to ignore all issues, specify "*".
DEPRECATED (not needed anymore, it is the default now). snap all new and modified components
DEPRECATED (use "--skip-tests" or "--unmodified" instead). force-snap even if tests are failing and even when component has not changed
description: EXPERIMENTAL. create an immutable and exportable component snapshot (no release version)
extendedDescription:
https://bit.dev/components/snaps
you can use a pattern for multiple ids, such as bit snap "utils/*". (wrap the pattern with quotes to avoid collision with shell commands)

arguments.name: component-pattern
arguments.description:
component name, component id, or component pattern. use component pattern to select multiple components.
use comma to separate patterns and "!" to exclude. e.g. "ui/**, !ui/button"
wrap the pattern with quotes. By default, all new and modified components are snapped.

name: reset [component-pattern] [component-version]
options: revert tag/snap for all tagged/snapped components
revert only soft-tags (components tagged with --soft flag)
revert the tag even if used as a dependency. WARNING: components that depend on this tag will corrupt
description: revert tagged or snapped versions for component(s)
extendedDescription: https://bit.dev/docs/components/tags#undoing-a-tag

arguments.name: component-pattern
arguments.description:
component name, component id, or component pattern. use component pattern to select multiple components.
use comma to separate patterns and "!" to exclude. e.g. "ui/**, !ui/button"
wrap the pattern with quotes

arguments.name: component-version
arguments.description: the version to untag (semver for tags. hash for snaps)

name: merge [values...]
options: in case of a conflict, override the used version with the current modification
in case of a conflict, override the current modification with the specified version
in case of a conflict, leave the files with a conflict state to resolve them manually later
EXPERIMENTAL. in case of an unresolved merge, revert to the state before the merge began
EXPERIMENTAL. mark an unresolved merge as resolved and create a new snap with the changes
EXPERIMENTAL. do not auto snap in case the merge completed without conflicts
in case of snap during the merge, run the build-pipeline (similar to bit snap --build)
EXPERIMENTAL. override the default message for the auto snap
description: merge changes of different component versions
extendedDescription:
merge changes of different component versions
  `bit merge <version> [ids...]` => merge changes of the given version into the checked out version
  `bit merge [ids...]` => EXPERIMENTAL. merge changes of the remote head into local, optionally use '--abort' or '--resolve'
  you can use a pattern for multiple ids, such as bit merge 0.0.1 "utils/*". (wrap the pattern with quotes to avoid collision with shell commands)

name: status
options: return a json version of the component
in case issues found, exit with code 1
description: present the current status of components in the workspace, and notifies when issues are detected

name: compile [component-names...]
options: compile only new and modified components
show more data, such as, dist paths
return the compile results in json format
delete existing dist folder before writing new compiled files
description: compile components in the workspace

arguments.name: component-names...
arguments.description: a list of component names or component IDs (defaults to all components)

name: run <app-name>
options: start the application in dev mode.
showing verbose output for inspection and prints stack trace
avoid running the watch process that compiles components in the background
description: run an app (independent of bit's dev server)

arguments.name: app-name
arguments.description: the app's name is registered by the app (run 'bit app list' to list the names of the available apps)

name: app-list
options: return the component data in json format
description: DEPRECATED. use "bit app list"

name: app <sub-command>
description: Manages apps

commands.name: list
options: return the component data in json format
commands.description: list all registered apps

name: test [component-pattern]
options: start the tester in watch mode.
start the tester in debug mode.
test all components, not only new and modified
write tests results as JUnit XML format into the specified file path
DEPRECATED. (use the pattern instead, e.g. "scopeName/**"). name of the scope to test
description: test components in the workspace

arguments.name: component-pattern
arguments.description:
component name, component id, or component pattern. use component pattern to select multiple components.
use comma to separate patterns and "!" to exclude. e.g. "ui/**, !ui/button"
wrap the pattern with quotes

name: schema <pattern>
options: return the component data in json format
description: shows the API schema of a certain component.
extendedDescription:
you can use a `<pattern>` for multiple component ids, such as `bit schema "org.scope/utils/**"`.
use comma to separate patterns and "!" to exclude. e.g. "ui/**, !ui/button"
always wrap the pattern with quotes to avoid collision with shell commands.
use `bit pattern --help` to understand patterns better and `bit pattern <pattern>` to validate the pattern.

name: check-types [component-pattern]
options: check-types for all components, not only modified and new
in case issues found, exit with code 1
description: check typescript types

arguments.name: component-pattern
arguments.description:
component name, component id, or component pattern. use component pattern to select multiple components.
use comma to separate patterns and "!" to exclude. e.g. "ui/**, !ui/button"
wrap the pattern with quotes

name: aspect <sub-command>
description: EXPERIMENTAL. manage aspects

commands.name: list [pattern]
options: show the origins were the aspects were taken from
commands.description: list all aspects configured on component(s)

arguments.name: pattern
arguments.description:
component name, component id, or component pattern. use component pattern to select multiple components. 
use comma to separate patterns and "!" to exclude. e.g. "ui/**, !ui/button"
wrap the pattern with quotes

commands.name: get <component-name>
options: show the origins were the aspects were taken from
commands.description: list the aspects set on a component, as well as their config and data

arguments.name: component-name
arguments.description: the component name or component id

commands.name: set <pattern> <aspect-id> [config]
commands.description: set components with an aspect to extend their development tools, metadata and (possibly) artifacts

arguments.name: pattern
arguments.description: the components to extend. use component name, component id, or component pattern. use component pattern to select multiple components. use comma to separate patterns and "!" to exclude. e.g. "ui/**, !ui/button". wrap the pattern with quotes

arguments.name: aspect-id
arguments.description: the aspect's component id

arguments.name: config
arguments.description: the aspect config. enter the config as a stringified JSON (e.g. '{"foo":"bar"}' ). when no config is provided, an aspect is set with an empty config ({}).

commands.name: unset <pattern> <aspect-id>
commands.description: unset an aspect from component(s).

arguments.name: pattern
arguments.description: the components to target. use component name, component id, or component pattern. use component pattern to select multiple components. use comma to separate patterns and "!" to exclude. e.g. "ui/**, !ui/button". wrap the pattern with quotes

arguments.name: aspect-id
arguments.description: the aspect's component id

commands.name: update <aspect-id> [pattern]
commands.description: update a version of an aspect

arguments.name: aspect-id
arguments.description: the aspect's component id

arguments.name: pattern
arguments.description: the components to update (defaults to all components). use component name, component id, or component pattern. use component pattern to select multiple components. use comma to separate patterns and "!" to exclude. e.g. "ui/**, !ui/button". wrap the pattern with quotes

examples.description: update "ui" components that use scope.org/aspect to use its latest version
update all components that use scope.org/aspect to version 2.0.0 (of this aspect).

name: clear-cache
options: clear memory cache from a remote scope
description: clears Bit's cache from current working machine
extendedDescription:
The following gets removed by this command:
1) V8 compiled code (generated the first time Bit is loaded by v8-compile-cache package)
2) components cache on the filesystem (mainly the dependencies graph and docs)
3) scope's index file, which maps the component-id:object-hash
https://bit.dev/docs/workspace/clearing-cache

name: log <id>
options: show log of a remote component
EXPERIMENTAL. show parents and lanes data
description: show components(s) version history
extendedDescription: https://bit.dev/docs/reference/cli-reference#log

arguments.name: id
arguments.description: component-id or component-name

name: deprecate <component-name>
options: if replaced by another component, enter the new component id
description: deprecate a component

arguments.name: component-name
arguments.description: component name or component id

name: undeprecate <id>
description: undeprecate a deprecated component (local/remote)

name: rename <current-name> <new-name>
options: default scope for the newly created component
relative path in the workspace. by default the path is `<scope>/<namespace>/<name>`
update the import/require statements in all dependent components (in the same workspace)
description: EXPERIMENTAL. rename component. if tagged/exported, create a new component and deprecate the original component

arguments.name: current-name
arguments.description: the current component name (without its scope name)

arguments.name: new-name
arguments.description: the new component name (without its scope name)

name: fork <source-component-id> [target-component-name]
options: default scope for the new component
relative path in the workspace for the new component. by default the path is `<scope>/<namespace>/<name>`
update the import/require statements in all dependent components (in the same workspace)
description: EXPERIMENTAL. create a new component out of an existing one (copies source files and config)

arguments.name: source-component-id
arguments.description: the component id of the source component

arguments.name: target-component-name
arguments.description: the name for the new component (component name without scope). to set a different scope, use the '--scope' flag

name: lane [lane-name]
options: show more details on the state of each component in each lane
show lanes details in json format
description:
show lanes details
https://bit.dev/docs/components/lanes

commands.name: list
options: show more details on the state of each component in each lane
show lanes details in a json format
show lanes that are not merged
commands.description: list lanes

commands.name: switch <lane>
options: relevant when the specified lane is a remote late. name a local lane differently than the remote lane
merge local changes with the checked out version. strategy should be "theirs", "ours" or "manual"
checkout all components in a lane include ones that do not exist in the workspace
do not install packages of the imported components
commands.description: switch to the specified lane

commands.name: show <lane-name>
options: show the lane details in json format
commands.description: show lane details

commands.name: create <lane-name>
options: remote scope where this lane will be exported to, default to the defaultScope (can be changed later with "bit lane change-scope")
a local alias to refer to this lane, defaults to the <lane-name> (can be added later with "bit lane alias")
commands.description: creates a new lane and switches to it
commands.extendedDescription:
a lane created from main (default-lane) is empty until components are snapped.
a lane created from another lane has all the components of the original lane.

arguments.name: lane-name
arguments.description: the name for the new lane

commands.name: merge <lane>
options: in case of a conflict, override the used version with the current modification
in case of a conflict, override the current modification with the specified version
in case of a conflict, leave the files with a conflict state to resolve them manually later
checkout only components in a lane that exist in the workspace
do not auto snap in case the merge completed without conflicts
in case of snap during the merge, run the build-pipeline (similar to bit snap --build)
override the default message for the auto snap
skip deleting the lane readme component after merging
EXPERIMENTAL. squash multiple snaps. keep the last one only
EXPERIMENTAL. partially merge the lane with the specified component-pattern
EXPERIMENTAL. relevant for "--pattern" and "--existing". merge also dependencies of the given components
commands.description: merge a local or a remote lane

commands.name: remove <lanes...>
options: remove a remote lane (in the lane arg, use remote/lane-id syntax)
removes the component from the scope, even if used as a dependency. WARNING: components that depend on this component will corrupt
commands.description: remove lanes

arguments.name: lanes...
arguments.description: A list of lane names, separated by spaces

commands.name: change-scope <lane-name> <remote-scope-name>
commands.description: changes the remote scope of a lane

commands.name: alias <lane-name> <alias>
commands.description: adds an alias to a lane
commands.extendedDescription:
an alias is a name that can be used to refer to a lane. it is saved locally and never reach the remote.
it is useful when having multiple lanes with the same name, but with different remote scopes.

commands.name: rename <current-name> <new-name>
commands.description: EXPERIMENTAL. change the lane-name locally and on the remote (if exported)

commands.name: diff [values...]
commands.description: show diff between lanes
commands.extendedDescription:
bit lane diff => diff between the current lane and default lane. (only inside workspace).
bit lane diff to => diff between the current lane (or default-lane when in scope) and "to" lane.
bit lane diff from to => diff between "from" lane and "to" lane.

commands.name: add-readme <component-name> [lane-name]
commands.description: EXPERIMENTAL. adds a readme component to a lane

arguments.name: component-id
arguments.description: the component name or id of the component to use as the lane's readme

arguments.name: lane-name
arguments.description: the lane to attach the readme to (defaults to the current lane)

commands.name: remove-readme [laneName]
commands.description: EXPERIMENTAL. remove lane readme component

commands.name: import <lane>
options: do not install packages of the imported components
commands.description: import a remote lane to your workspace

arguments.name: lane
arguments.description: the remote lane name

name: switch <lane>
options: relevant when the specified lane is a remote late. name a local lane differently than the remote lane
merge local changes with the checked out version. strategy should be "theirs", "ours" or "manual"
checkout all components in a lane include ones that do not exist in the workspace
do not install packages of the imported components
description: switch to the specified lane

name: eject <component-pattern>
options: ignore local version. remove the components even when they are staged or modified
print the results in JSON format
keep the component files in the workspace intact
description: replace components maintained in the workspace with their corresponding packages

arguments.name: component-pattern
arguments.description:
component name, component id, or component pattern.
use component pattern to select multiple components. use comma to separate patterns and "!" to exclude. e.g. "ui/**, !ui/button"
wrap the pattern with quotes

name: resume-export <export-id> <remotes...>
description: EXPERIMENTAL. resume failed export
extendedDescription:
resume failed export to persist the pending objects on the given remotes.
the export-id is the id the client got in the error message during the failure.
alternatively, exporting to any one of the failed scopes, throws server-is-busy error with the export-id

name: export [component-names...]
options: replace the exported components with their corresponding packages (to use these components without further maintaining them)
export not only staged versions but all of them
EXPERIMENTAL. avoid export to the central hub, instead, export directly to the original scopes. not recommended!
in case the previous export failed and suggested to resume with an export-id, enter the id
EXPERIMENTAL. don't throw an error when artifact files are missing. not recommended, unless you're sure the artifacts are in the remote
description: export components from the workspace to remote scopes
extendedDescription:
bit export => export all staged components to their current scope, if checked out to a lane, export the lane as well
`bit export [id...]` => export the given ids to their current scope

https://bit.dev/docs/components/exporting-components
you can use a pattern for multiple ids, such as bit export remote-scope "utils/*". (wrap the pattern with quotes to avoid collision with shell commands)

arguments.name: component-names...
arguments.description: a list of component names or component IDs (separated by space). By default, all new component versions are exported.

name: update-dependencies <data>
options: tag once the build is completed (by default it snaps)
simulation purpose. should never be pushed (otherwise, flattened-deps are invalid)
export the updated objects to the original scopes once tagged/snapped
message to be saved as part of the version log
username to be saved as part of the version log
email to be saved as part of the version log
avoid throwing an error when running on a non-new scope
description: update dependencies for components and tag/snap the results
extendedDescription:
this command should be running from a new bare scope, it first imports the components it needs and then processes the update.
the input data is a stringified JSON of an array of the following object.
{
  componentId: string; // ids always have scope, so it's safe to parse them from string
  dependencies: string[]; // e.g. [teambit/compiler@1.0.0, teambit/tester@1.0.0]
  versionToTag?: string; // specific version (e.g. '1.0.0') or semver (e.g. 'minor', 'patch')
}
an example of the final data: '[{"componentId":"ci.remote2/comp-b","dependencies":["ci.remote/comp1@0.0.2"]}]'

name: sign [component...]
options: exit with code 0 even though the build failed
export the updated objects to the original scopes once done
helps to fetch the components from the lane scope (relevant for --multiple)
description: complete the build process for components
extendedDescription:
without --multiple, this will be running on the original scope.
with --multiple, a new bare-scope needs to be created and it will import the components to this scope first

name: format [component...]
options: format only new and modified components
will output a human-friendly message and a list of unformatted files, if any
return the format results in json format
description: format components in the development workspace

name: lint [component...]
options: lint only new and modified components
specify the types of fixes to apply (problem, suggestion, layout)
return the lint results in json format
description: lint components in the development workspace
